According to William of Tyre's "Deeds Done Beyond the Sea," Reynald de Chatillon, a prominent figure during the Crusades and the Lord of Kerak and Montréal, covered a group of Muslim prisoners with honey and left them on the roof of his castle to be attacked by bees and other insects. This cruel and inhumane act was considered a violation of the chivalric code of conduct and provoked outrage among both Christian and Muslim leaders.

Reynald was known for his aggressive actions against Muslims, including raids on Muslim caravans and territories. He was eventually captured by the Muslim leader Saladin in 1187 and executed for his actions. The incident of covering Muslim prisoners with honey and leaving them on the roof is often cited as an example of Reynald's brutality and disregard for human life.
